member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Implementation.Synchronization.ICodeManagerSynchronizationPoint
member.summary: This interface is an implementation detail of to enable synchronization of code generation functionalities in one place.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.CodeGeneration.IGeneratedCodeFlusher
member.summary: Instances of this interface manage the code generated by the pipeline.
member.remarks: Implementations of this interface must not use other pipeline APIs themselves as this could cause deadlocks in a multi-threaded environment.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.CodeGeneration.IGeneratedCodeFlusher.SetAssemblyDirectory(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the directory in that assemblies will be saved, when is called. If is specified, the assemblies are saved to the current working directory.
member.param: The assembly directory, or .
member.exception: If the pipeline already generated a type (because it was requested) into the new assembly, the assembly directory cannot be changed.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.CodeGeneration.IGeneratedCodeFlusher.SetAssemblyNamePattern(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the assembly name pattern, that is, a pattern used to determine the assembly name the next time is invoked. To ensure unique assembly file names use the placeholder {counter}, which will be replaced with a unique number. If the name pattern does not contain the placeholder, calls to will overwrite previously saved assemblies.
member.remarks: Note that the assembly name pattern should not include a file extension (.dll).
member.param: The assembly name pattern (might include {counter} placeholder; should not include the .dll file extension).
member.exception: If the pipeline already generated a type (because it was requested) into the new assembly, the assembly name pattern cannot be changed.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.CodeGeneration.IGeneratedCodeFlusher.FlushCodeToDisk(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Remotion.TypePipe.MutableReflection.CustomAttributeDeclaration})
member.summary: Saves all types that have been generated since the last call to this method into a new on disk. The file name of the assembly is derived from plus the file ending .dll. The assembly is written to the directory defined by . If is the assembly is saved in the current working directory.
member.param: A number of custom s that are attached to the assembly.
member.remarks: If no new types have been generated since the last call to , this method does nothing and returns .
member.returns: The absolute path to the saved assembly file, or if no assembly was saved.

member.name: P:Remotion.TypePipe.CodeGeneration.IGeneratedCodeFlusher.AssemblyDirectory
member.summary: Gets the directory in which assemblies will be saved when is invoked; means the current working directory.

member.name: P:Remotion.TypePipe.CodeGeneration.IGeneratedCodeFlusher.AssemblyNamePattern
member.summary: Gets the current assembly name pattern, that is, a pattern used to determine the assembly name the next time is invoked. To ensure unique assembly file names use the placeholder {counter}, which will be replaced with a unique number. If the name pattern does not contain the placeholder, calls to will overwrite previously saved assemblies.
member.value: The assembly name pattern; the default is TypePipe_GeneratedAssembly_{counter}.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression.ReturnReadOnly``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0}@)
member.summary:
Helper used for ensuring we only return 1 instance of a ReadOnlyCollection of T.
This is called from various methods where we internally hold onto an IList of T or a readonly collection of T. We check to see if we've already returned a readonly collection of T and if so simply return the other one. Otherwise we do a thread-safe replacement of the list w/ a readonly collection which wraps it.
Ultimately this saves us from having to allocate a ReadOnlyCollection for our data types because the compiler is capable of going directly to the IList of T.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression.ReturnReadOnly(Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.IArgumentProvider,System.Object@)
member.summary:
Helper used for ensuring we only return 1 instance of a ReadOnlyCollection of T.
This is similar to the ReturnReadOnly of T. This version supports nodes which hold onto multiple Expressions where one is typed to object. That object field holds either an expression or a ReadOnlyCollection of Expressions. When it holds a ReadOnlyCollection the IList which backs it is a ListArgumentProvider which uses the Expression which implements IArgumentProvider to get 2nd and additional values. The ListArgumentProvider continues to hold onto the 1st expression.
This enables users to get the ReadOnlyCollection w/o it consuming more memory than if it was just an array. Meanwhile The DLR internally avoids accessing which would force the readonly collection to be created resulting in a typical memory savings.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression.ReturnObject``1(System.Object)
member.summary:
Helper which is used for specialized subtypes which use ReturnReadOnly(ref object, ...). This is the reverse version of ReturnReadOnly which takes an IArgumentProvider.
This is used to return the 1st argument. The 1st argument is typed as object and either contains a ReadOnlyCollection or the Expression. We check for the Expression and if it's present we return that, otherwise we return the 1st element of the ReadOnlyCollection.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Caching.ICacheKeyProvider
member.summary: This interface provides a cache key for a from the requested or generated type. Implementations should return non-equal cache keys if the participant applies different modifications to the . This might depend on participant configuation, context and user options. However, a cache key should not encode the requested type itself, as this is already handled by the pipeline caching facilities.
member.remarks: This interface must be implemented if the generated types cannot be cached unconditionally. If the generated types can be cached unconditionally should return .

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Caching.ICacheKeyProvider.GetCacheKey(System.Type)
member.summary: Gets a cache key used to identify the assembled for the provided requested .
member.remarks: The cache key should include the configuration of this and other data that might influence the modifications specified by the . Implementations should not encode the requested type itself, as this is already handled by the pipeline.
member.param: The requested type.
member.returns: A cache key, or if no specific caching information is required for the .

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Caching.ICacheKeyProvider.RebuildCacheKey(System.Type,System.Type)
member.summary: Rebuilds a cache key from an assembled . This method is the counterpart of and will be invoked when types are loaded from an flushed assembly. The compound cache key from all participants determines whether or not an assembled type is loaded into the .
member.remarks: The cache key should include the configuration of this and other data that might influence the modifications specified by the . Implementations should not encode the requested type, i.e., the base type of , as this is already handled by the pipeline.
member.param: The requested type.
The loaded assembled type.
member.returns: A cache key, or if no specific caching information is required for the .

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.IPipelineRegistry
member.summary: Allows the registration of an instance under a given participant configuration ID and retrieving that pipeline later via the same identifier. An instance of this interface should be retrievable via the service locator or an IoC container. This allows users to register and resolve global instances used throughout an application.
member.remarks: This interface also enables serialization of object instances without the need to save the generated types to disk. To accomplish this register compatible pipelines under the same participant configuration ID in the deserializing as well as the serializing app domain. Compatible pipelines refers to pipelines with equivalent participant configurations, i.e., pipelines that generate equivalent types for a requested type.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.CallInfo
member.summary: Describes arguments in the dynamic binding process.
member.remarks:
ArgumentCount - all inclusive number of arguments. ArgumentNames - names for those arguments that are named.
Argument names match to the argument values in left to right order and last name corresponds to the last argument.
Example: Foo(arg1, arg2, arg3, name1 = arg4, name2 = arg5, name3 = arg6)
will correspond to: ArgumentCount: 6 ArgumentNames: {"name1", "name2", "name3"}

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.DynamicObject
member.summary:
Provides a simple class that can be inherited from to create an object with dynamic behavior at runtime. Subclasses can override the various binder methods (GetMember, SetMember, Call, etc...) to provide custom behavior that will be invoked at runtime.
If a method is not overridden then the DynamicObject does not directly support that behavior and the call site will determine how the binding should be performed.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.IDynamicMetaObjectProvider
member.summary: Represents a dynamic object, that can have its operations bound at runtime.
member.remarks: Objects that want to participate in the binding process should implement an IDynamicMetaObjectProvider interface, and implement to return a .

member.summary: Returns the responsible for binding operations performed on this object.
member.param: The expression tree representation of the runtime value.
member.returns: The to bind this object.

member.summary: Represents a dynamically assigned class. Expando objects which share the same members will share the same class. Classes are dynamically assigned as the expando object gains members.

member.summary: Constructs a new ExpandoClass that can hold onto the specified keys. The keys must be sorted ordinally. The hash code must be precalculated for the keys.

member.summary: Finds or creates a new ExpandoClass given the existing set of keys in this ExpandoClass plus the new key to be added. Members in an ExpandoClass are always stored case sensitively.

member.summary: Gets the lists of transitions that are valid from this ExpandoClass to an ExpandoClass whos keys hash to the apporopriate hash code.

member.summary: Gets the index at which the value should be stored for the specified name case sensitively. Returns the index even if the member is marked as deleted.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.ExpandoClass.GetValueIndexCaseInsensitive(System.String,Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.ExpandoObject)
member.summary: Gets the index at which the value should be stored for the specified name, the method is only used in the case-insensitive case.
member.param: the name of the member
The ExpandoObject associated with the class that is used to check if a member has been deleted.
member.returns: the exact match if there is one if there is exactly one member with case insensitive match, return it otherwise we throw AmbiguousMatchException.

member.name: P:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.ExpandoClass.Keys

member.summary: Represents an object with members that can be dynamically added and removed at runtime.

member.summary: Try to get the data stored for the specified class at the specified index. If the class has changed a full lookup for the slot will be performed and the correct value will be retrieved.

member.summary: Sets the data for the specified class at the specified index. If the class has changed then a full look for the slot will be performed. If the new class does not have the provided slot then the Expando's class will change. Only case sensitive setter is supported in ExpandoObject.

member.summary: Returns true if the member at the specified index has been deleted, otherwise false. Call this function holding the lock.

member.summary: Exposes the ExpandoClass which we've associated with this Expando object. Used for type checks in rules.

member.summary: Gets the class and the index associated with the given name. Does not update the expando object. Instead this returns both the original and desired new class. A rule is created which includes the test for the original class, the promotion to the new class, and the set/delete based on the class post-promotion.

member.name: P:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.IInvokeOnGetBinder.InvokeOnGet
member.summary: Gets the value indicating if this GetMember should invoke properties when performing the get. The default value when this interface is not present is true.
member.remarks: This property is used by some languages to get a better COM interop experience. When the value is set to false, the dynamic COM object won't invoke the object but will instead bind to the name, and return an object that can be invoked or indexed later. This is useful for indexed properties and languages that don't produce InvokeMember call sites.

member.summary: Creates a new expression that is like this one, but using the supplied children. If all of the children are the same, it will return this expression.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.BlockExpression.Rewrite(System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection{Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.ParameterExpression},Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression[])
member.summary:
Makes a copy of this node replacing the parameters/args with the provided values. The shape of the parameters/args needs to match the shape of the current block - in other words there should be the same # of parameters and args.
parameters can be null in which case the existing parameters are used.
This helper is provided to allow re-writing of nodes to not depend on the specific optimized subclass of BlockExpression which is being used.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.BlockExpression.ReturnReadOnlyExpressions(Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.BlockExpression,System.Object@)
member.summary:
Helper used for ensuring we only return 1 instance of a ReadOnlyCollection of T.
This is similar to the ReturnReadOnly which only takes a single argument. This version supports nodes which hold onto 5 Expressions and puts all of the arguments into the ReadOnlyCollection.
Ultimately this means if we create the readonly collection we will be slightly more wasteful as we'll have a readonly collection + some fields in the type. The DLR internally avoids accessing anything which would force the readonly collection to be created.
This is used by BlockExpression5 and MethodCallExpression5.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.BlockExpressionList
member.summary: Provides a wrapper around an IArgumentProvider which exposes the argument providers members out as an IList of Expression. This is used to avoid allocating an array which needs to be stored inside of a ReadOnlyCollection. Instead this type has the same amount of overhead as an array without duplicating the storage of the elements. This ensures that internally we can avoid creating and copying arrays while users of the Expression trees also don't pay a size penalty for this internal optimization. See IArgumentProvider for more general information on the Expression tree optimizations being used here.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.DynamicExpression
member.summary: Represents a dynamic operation.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.IArgumentProvider
member.summary:
Provides an internal interface for accessing the arguments that multiple tree nodes (DynamicExpression, ElementInit, MethodCallExpression, InvocationExpression, NewExpression, and InexExpression).
This enables two optimizations which reduce the size of the trees. The first is it enables the nodes to hold onto an IList of T instead of a ReadOnlyCollection. This saves the cost of allocating the ReadOnlyCollection for each node. The second is that it enables specialized subclasses to be created which hold onto a specific number of arguments. For example Block2, Block3, Block4. These nodes can therefore avoid allocating both a ReadOnlyCollection and an array for storing their elements saving 32 bytes per node.
Meanwhile the nodes can continue to expose the original LINQ properties of ReadOnlyCollections. They do this by re-using 1 field for storing both the array or an element that would normally be stored in the array.
For the array case the collection is typed to IList of T instead of ReadOnlyCollection of T. When the node is initially constructed it is an array. When the compiler accesses the members it uses this interface. If a user accesses the members the array is promoted to a ReadOnlyCollection.
For the object case we store the 1st argument in a field typed to object and when the node is initially constructed this holds directly onto the Expression. When the compiler accesses the members it again uses this interface and the accessor for the 1st argument uses Expression.ReturnObject to return the object which handles the Expression or ReadOnlyCollection case. When the user accesses the ReadOnlyCollection then the object field is updated to hold directly onto the ReadOnlyCollection.
It is important that the Expressions consistently return the same ReadOnlyCollection otherwise the re-writer will be broken and it would be a breaking change from LINQ v1. The problem is that currently users can rely on object identity to tell if the node has changed. Storing the readonly collection in an overloaded field enables us to both reduce memory usage as well as maintain compatibility and an easy to use external API.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.DynamicExpression.Rewrite(Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression[])
member.summary:
Makes a copy of this node replacing the args with the provided values. The number of the args needs to match the number of the current block.
This helper is provided to allow re-writing of nodes to not depend on the specific optimized subclass of DynamicExpression which is being used.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.ListArgumentProvider
member.summary: Provides a wrapper around an IArgumentProvider which exposes the argument providers members out as an IList of Expression. This is used to avoid allocating an array which needs to be stored inside of a ReadOnlyCollection. Instead this type has the same amount of overhead as an array without duplicating the storage of the elements. This ensures that internally we can avoid creating and copying arrays while users of the Expression trees also don't pay a size penalty for this internal optimization. See IArgumentProvider for more general information on the Expression tree optimizations being used here.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.TryExpression
member.summary:
Represents a try/catch/finally/fault block.
The body is protected by the try block. The handlers consist of a set of s that can either be catch or filters. The fault runs if an exception is thrown. The finally runs regardless of how control exits the body. Only one of fault or finally can be supplied. The return type of the try block must match the return type of any associated catch statements.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.Utils.TypeUtils.GetBooleanOperator(System.Type,System.String)
member.summary:
Searches for an operator method on the type. The method must have the specified signature, no generic arguments, and have the SpecialName bit set. Also searches inherited operator methods.
NOTE: This was designed to satisfy the needs of op_True and op_False, because we have to do runtime lookup for those. It may not work right for unary operators in general.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.Utils.TypeUtils.CanCache(System.Type)
member.summary: We can cache references to types, as long as they aren't in collectable assemblies. Unfortunately, we can't really distinguish between different flavors of assemblies. But, we can at least create a whitelist for types in mscorlib (so we get the primitives) and System.Core (so we find Func/Action overloads, etc).

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.CompilerScope
member.summary:
CompilerScope is the data structure which the Compiler keeps information related to compiling scopes. It stores the following information: 1. Parent relationship (for resolving variables) 2. Information about hoisted variables 3. Information for resolving closures
Instances are produced by VariableBinder, which does a tree walk looking for scope nodes: LambdaExpression and BlockExpression.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.LambdaCompiler.EmitExpressionAndBranch(System.Boolean,Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression,System.Reflection.Emit.Label)
member.summary: Emits the expression and then either brtrue/brfalse to the label.
member.param: True for brtrue, false for brfalse.
The expression to emit.
The label to conditionally branch to.
member.remarks:
This function optimizes equality and short circuiting logical operators to avoid double-branching, minimize instruction count, and generate similar IL to the C# compiler. This is important for the JIT to optimize patterns like: x != null AndAlso x.GetType() == typeof(SomeType)
One optimization we don't do: we always emits at least one conditional branch to the label, and always possibly falls through, even if we know if the branch will always succeed or always fail. We do this to avoid generating unreachable code, which is fine for the CLR JIT, but doesn't verify with peverify.
This kind of optimization could be implemented safely, by doing constant folding over conditionals and logical expressions at the tree level.

member.summary: Creates the label for this case. Optimization: if the body is just a goto, and we can branch to it, put the goto target directly in the jump table.

member.summary: Analyzes a lambda, producing a new one that has correct invariants for codegen. In particular, it spills the IL stack to temps in places where it's invalid to have a non-empty stack (for example, entering a try statement).

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.Clone``1(System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection{``0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Will clone an IList into an array of the same size, and copy all vaues up to (and NOT including) the max index
member.returns: The cloned array.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.RequireNoRefArgs(System.Reflection.MethodBase)
member.summary:
If we are spilling, requires that there are no byref arguments to the method call.
Used for: NewExpression, MethodCallExpression, InvocationExpression, DynamicExpression, UnaryExpression, BinaryExpression.
member.remarks: We could support this if spilling happened later in the compiler. Other expressions that can emit calls with arguments (such as ListInitExpression and IndexExpression) don't allow byref arguments.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.RequireNotRefInstance(Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression)
member.summary:
Requires that the instance is not a value type (primitive types are okay because they're immutable).
Used for: MethodCallExpression, MemberExpression (for properties), IndexExpression, ListInitExpression, MemberInitExpression, assign to MemberExpression, assign to IndexExpression.
member.remarks: We could support this if spilling happened later in the compiler.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.RewriteExpression(Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression,Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.Stack)
member.summary: Rewrite the expression
member.param: Expression to rewrite
State of the stack before the expression is emitted.
member.returns: Rewritten expression.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.ToTemp(Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression,Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression@)
member.summary: Will perform: save: temp = expression return value: temp

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.MakeBlock(Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression[])
member.summary: Creates a special block that is marked as not allowing jumps in. This should not be used for rewriting BlockExpression itself, or anything else that supports jumping.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.MakeBlock(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression})
member.summary: Creates a special block that is marked as not allowing jumps in. This should not be used for rewriting BlockExpression itself, or anything else that supports jumping.

member.name: F:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.TempMaker._temp
member.summary: Current temporary variable

member.name: F:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.TempMaker._freeTemps
member.summary: List of free temporary variables. These can be recycled for new temps.

member.name: F:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.TempMaker._usedTemps
member.summary: Stack of currently active temporary variables.

member.name: F:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.TempMaker._temps
member.summary: List of all temps created by stackspiller for this rule/lambda

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.StackSpiller.ChildRewriter
member.summary:
Rewrites child expressions, spilling them into temps if needed. The stack starts in the inital state, and after the first subexpression is added it is change to non-empty. This behavior can be overridden by setting the stack manually between adds.
When all children have been added, the caller should rewrite the node if Rewrite is true. Then, it should call Finish with etiher the orignal expression or the rewritten expression. Finish will call Expression.Comma if necessary and return a new Result.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.SpilledExpressionBlock
member.summary: A special subtype of BlockExpression that indicates to the compiler that this block is a spilled expression and should not allow jumps in.

member.summary: Generator of PDB debugging information for expression trees.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Compiler.VariableBinder
member.summary: Determines if variables are closed over in nested lambdas and need to be hoisted.

This class is not thread safe.

member.summary: Creates a dictionary-like object used for caches.
member.param: The maximum number of elements to store.

member.summary: Tries to get the value associated with 'key', returning true if it's found and false if it's not present.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.Utils.CacheDict`2.Add(`0,`1)
member.summary: Adds a new element to the cache, replacing and moving it to the front if the element is already present.

member.name: P:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.Utils.CacheDict`2.Item(`0)
member.summary: Returns the value associated with the given key, or throws KeyNotFoundException if the key is not present.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Dynamic.Utils.CollectionExtensions.ToReadOnly``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary:
Wraps the provided enumerable into a ReadOnlyCollection{T}
Copies all of the data into a new array, so the data can't be changed after creation. The exception is if the enumerable is already a ReadOnlyCollection{T}, in which case we just return it.

member.summary:
Returns true if the method's parameter types are reference assignable from the argument types, otherwise false.
An example that can make the method return false is that typeof(double).GetMethod("op_Equality", ..., new[] { typeof(double), typeof(int) }) returns a method with two double parameters, which doesn't match the provided argument types.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.MutableReflection.MutableType.AddInitialization(System.Func{Remotion.TypePipe.MutableReflection.BodyBuilding.InitializationBodyContext,Remotion.TypePipe.Dlr.Ast.Expression})
member.summary: Adds instance initialization code. The initialization code is executed exactly once after object creation or deserialization.

remarks.note: The fact that the instance initialization code is executed after deserialization means that side effects may be applied twice, once when the original object is constructed and once when it is (later) deserialized.
remarks.para: The added initializations are not executed when instances of the type are created directly through the API, which creates an object of a type without invoking any constructor. Such instances must be prepared with before usage.

member.param: A provider returning an instance initialization.

member.name: M:Remotion.TypePipe.MutableReflection.MutableType.GetOrAddOverride(System.Reflection.MethodInfo)
member.summary: Returns a that can be used to modify the behavior of the given .
member.param: The to get a for.
member.returns: The corresponding to , an override for a base method or an implementation for an interface method.
member.remarks:
Depending on the of this method returns the following.
Proxy type
The corresponding from the collection.
Base type
An existing mutable override for the base method, or
a newly created override (implicit; or explicit if necessary).
Interface type
An existing mutable implementation, or
a newly created implementation, or
an existing mutable override for a base implementation, or
a newly created override for a base implementation (implicit; or explicit if necessary).

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.IParticipant
member.summary: Participates in the assembly of a type by calling mutating members of . Framework authors implement this interface in order to take part in the code generation process.

remarks.para: Instances of this interface are used to populate . Every participant has the chance the specify type modifications via the provided instance. The is a representation of the type to be generated for the requested type. In addition, it contains all modifications applied by preceding participants in the pipeline.

Note that implementations of this interface may be shared across multiple instances. Participants therefore must not hold any mutable state directly. If there is the need to hold state a participant should use .

member.param: The type assembly context.

member.name: T:Remotion.TypePipe.Serialization.SerializationParticipant
member.summary: Enables the serialization of modified type instances without the need of saving the generated assembly to disk.
member.remarks:
Serialization is enabled by adding additional metadata to the serialization payload and using a serialization helper for deserialization. The helper uses the metadata to regenerate a compatible type. The metadata includes the following items:
Type of the serialization helper which should be used for deserialization.
The assembly-qualified type name of the underlying type.
Object factory identifier that will be used to retrieve the object factory during deserialization.
